choices.text: Appears plump due to increased deposition of fat in adipose tissue.
Has markedly decreased weight for height.
Displays abdominal and peripheral edema.
Has a serum albumin level above normal.

questions.text: A child in the clinical photograph has been diagnosed with kwashiorkor. Considering the characteristics of kwashiorkor, which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Displays abdominal and peripheral edema. 

 

Option C:      

                     

  • Kwashiorkor is a Protein energy malnutrition caused by inadequate intake of protein with good calorie intake.
  • C/F: abdominal and peripheral oedema (swollen belly and legs) due to decreased serum albumin levels.
  • Body fat stores are depleted, but weight for height is normal.
  • Treatment – diet adequate in calories and protein.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Appears plump due to increased deposition of fat in adipose tissue: Swollen belly and legs are due to decreased serum albumin levels, not due to fat deposition.

 

Option B. Has markedly decreased weight for height: Weight for height is normal.

 

Option D. Has a serum albumin level above normal: Decreased serum albumin levels.

 

Educational objective:

 

Kwashiorkor is a form of severe protein-energy malnutrition characterized by edema, enlarged liver with fatty infiltrates, and other signs. The abdominal and peripheral edema contribute to the plump appearance of the child, which can mask weight loss. This condition is typically associated with a diet high in calories but extremely low in protein, leading to hypoalbuminemia, which contributes to the edema seen in such patients.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 535-536, Lippincott 6/e: p 369-370

choices.text: Decreases risk of cardiovascular disease
Increases risk of diabetes mellitus

questions.text: When examining the effects of dietary fiber on health, which of the following is NOT a recognized benefit of dietary fiber consumption?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increases risk of diabetes mellitus

 

Option D:

 

  1. Diet rich in fiber:
  •  Improves bowel motility
  • Prevents constipation
  • Decreases reabsorption of bile acids → lowering cholesterol level and improves glucose tolerance.
  1. Has hypoglycemic and hypolipidemic effects.
  2. The beneficial effect is more with soluble fiber seen in vegetables and only a diet having plenty of vegetables and green leaves will have the desired effect.
  3.  

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increases stool bulk: True, as fiber adds bulk to the stool and facilitates bowel movements, preventing constipation.

 

Option B. Lowers cholesterol level: True, certain types of soluble fiber can help reduce blood cholesterol levels by interfering with the absorption of dietary cholesterol.

 

Option C. Decreases risk of cardiovascular disease: True, through mechanisms like lowering blood cholesterol levels and improving blood pressure, dietary fiber contributes to cardiovascular health.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Health effects

  1. Reduces constipation and hemorrhoid formation, softens stools
  2. Increases bowel motility, thus reducing exposure of gut to carcinogens
  3. Decreases absorption of dietary fat and cholesterol
  4. Increases fecal loss of cholesterol
  5. Delays gastric emptying
  6. Generates sensation of fullness
  7. Reduces postprandial blood glucose concentration

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 531.

questions.text: During an inspection of a region where Protein-Energy Malnutrition (PEM) is prevalent, a medical team aims to assess the quality of protein available in the local diet. Which of the following indicators would provide the best measure of protein quality in this context?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Net protein utilization                                                  

 

Option A:

 

Net protein utilization (NPU) is an excellent indicator for assessing protein quality, as it takes into account both the digestibility of the protein and its amino acid profile in relation to body needs. NPU provides a measure of the proportion of ingested protein that is actually used for protein synthesis in the body, making it highly relevant for evaluating dietary protein in a PEM-prevalent area.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Digestibility Coefficient: Is the proportion of food that is digested compared to what is absorbed, expressed in %.

 

Option C. Biological value of protein: ratio between the amount of nitrogen retained and nitrogen absorbed during a specific interval.

 

Option D. Amino acid score: In combination with protein digestibility, used to determine whether the protein is complete or not.

 

Educational objective:

 

The following indices are used to assess the nutritional value of proteins:

 

  • Biological Value (BV) of Protein: It is the ratio between the amount of nitrogen retained and nitrogen absorbed during a specific interval
  • Net Protein Utilization (NPU):     NPU = Retained nitrogen / intake of nitrogen × 100
  • Net Dietary Protein Value (NDPV): This will assess both quantity and quality of the proteins in the diet.    NDPV=Intake of N × 6.25 × NPU
  • Protein Efficiency Ratio (PER): It is the weight gain per gram of protein taken.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 534.

questions.text: A middle-aged male who consumes a diet containing 100 grams of protein per day is found to excrete 25 grams of nitrogen in his urine daily. Considering the normal nitrogen content in dietary protein and the expected balance in a healthy adult, what does this most likely indicate about his physiological state?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clinically ill

 

Explanation:

                                                           

Nitrogen balance can be measured by calculating the dietary intake of protein nitrogen (16% of the weight of ingested proteins) and then comparing it with the daily nitrogen excretion.

 

A normal healthy adult is said to be in nitrogen balance if the dietary intake of nitrogen (I) = daily loss in urine (U) + feces (F) + skin (S). l=U+F+S

In the above scenario, the person ingests 100 g (which amounts in 16 g of ingested nitrogen) of proteins/day and excretes 25 g of nitrogen/day. 

 

Hence, the rate of nitrogen excretion is more than that of ingestion and the person is in a state of negative nitrogen balance which is common in illness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal healthy individual: Dietary intake of Nitrogen = Daily loss of Nitrogen

 

Option B. Pregnant lady: Positive nitrogen balance due to the growth of fetus

 

Option C. Convalescence: Convalescing after an illness or surgery will be in positive nitrogen balance.

 

Educational objective:

 

A negative nitrogen balance, where nitrogen loss exceeds intake, can indicate catabolic stress due to illness, trauma, or other conditions requiring clinical intervention. It underscores the need for careful dietary and clinical management in individuals presenting with such an imbalance.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 553-554.

choices.text: The dietary proportions of carbohydrate, protein and fat in the given scenario is as per current recommendations
Total energy intake /day is 3,000 kcal.
Diet consumed is fibre rich

questions.text: A 60-kg man has a daily diet that includes an average of 275g of carbohydrates, 75g of protein, and 65g of fat. Based on this information, which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The dietary proportions of carbohydrate, protein and fat in the given scenario is as per current recommendations.       

 

Option A:

                                                                          

  • The total energy intake is calculated as –

= (275 g carbohydrate × 4 kcal/g) + (75 g protein × 4 kcal/g) + (65 g fat × 9 kcal/g)

= 1,100 + 300 + 585

= 1,985 total kcal/day

 

  • The percentage calories from

Carbohydrate:  1,100/1,985 = 55

Protein:  300/1,985    = 15

Fat:   585/1,985    = 30

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Total energy intake /day is 3,000 kcal: It is 1,985 total kcal/day.

 

Option C. FAT forms 40% of calories: It forms only 30% of calories.

 

Option D. Diet consumed is fibre rich: The amount of fiber in the diet cannot be found from the given data presented.

 

Educational objective:

 

The total energy intake is calculated as = (carbohydrate × 4 kcal/g) + (protein × 4 kcal/g) + (fat × 9 kcal/g)

 

Ref: Lippincott 7/e: P 358 – 360.

questions.text:
Two young brothers aged 3.5 and 2.5, from a low socioeconomic status background, present with generalized swelling, distended abdomens, and are primarily consuming rice with no inclusion of pulses, fruits, or vegetables in their diet. On examination, both appear lethargic with mild hepatomegaly, ascites, pitting edema in the lower limbs, scaling skin, and hypopigmented bands in their hair. Laboratory results show hypoalbuminemia.

 

 

Child A: Total protein: 6.1 g/dl, albumin: 3.0 g/dl Child B: Total protein: 5.7 g/dl, albumin: 2.7 g/dl

 

What is the most likely diagnosis for these children?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kwashiorkor

 

Option A:

 

  • Kwashiorkor is a Protein energy malnutrition caused by inadequate intake of protein with good calorie intake.
  • C/F: abdominal and peripheral edema due to decreased serum albumin levels.
  • Body fat stores are depleted, but weight for height is normal.
  • Treatment – diet adequate in calories and protein.
  • The hallmark features of Kwashiorkor are hypalbuminaemia, poor wound healing and oedema.
  • Hypoalbuminemia: If the albumin values << 2 g/dL is a biochemical marker in cases of Kwashiorkor (Marasmus: not so low).
  • IgG increases due to associated infections.
  • Fatty liver is seen in Kwashiorkor due to decreased lipoprotein synthesis, but not in marasmus.
  • Glucose tolerance is often normal, but hypoglycaemia may be seen in marasmus.
  • Hypokalaemia and dehydration is seen when there is diarrhoea.
  • Hypomagnesaemia is present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Marasmus is a PEM due to inadequate intake of calorie, usually seen in children << 1year of age when breast milk is supplemented with watery gruels of native cereals which are deficient in both protein and calories. C/F: Arrested growth, extreme muscle wasting and loss of subcutaneous fat (emaciation), weakness and anemia.

 

Option C. Obesity is the condition in which excess fat is accumulated due to the increased energy intake and decreased energy expenditure.

 

Option D. Irritable bowel syndrome is a G.I disorder of unknown cause. C/F: abdominal cramps or pain, bloating, flatulence, alternating periods of diarrhoea and constipation etc.

 

Educational objective:

 

Edema, protruded abdomen, changes in hair pigmentation, and hypoalbuminemia is characteristic of kwashiorkor, a form of malnutrition caused by inadequate protein intake despite sufficient caloric consumption. The staple diet of rice, lacking in essential amino acids, supports this diagnosis.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 535.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old child brought to the hospital with severe weight loss, irritability and repeated infection. He has 4 siblings. His father is a farmer. O/E, child seems emaciated with dry and shrunken eye with a prominent bony rib cage and had labored breathing. His body weight is 7 kg.

 

 

Laboratory investigations:

 

  • Blood glucose: 60 mg/dl (normal random= 80-140 mg/dl)
  • Total protein: 6.8 g/dl (normal=5.5-8.5 g/dl)
  • Albumin: 3.3 g/dl (normal =3.5-5.5 g/dl)

 

What disease is the baby suffering from?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Marasmus

 

Option B:

 

  • It is a Protein energy malnutrition due to inadequate intake of calorie.
  • Marasmus occurs when calorie deprivation is more than the reduction in protein.
  • It is usually seen in children << 1year of age when breast milk is supplemented with watery gruels of native cereals which are deficient in both protein and calories.
  • C/F: Arrested growth, extreme muscle wasting and loss of subcutaneous fat (emaciation), weakness and anaemia.
  • BIOCHEMICAL ALTERATIONS: Hypoalbuminemia: albumin values << 2 g/Dl in cases of Kwashiorkor. In Marasmus: not so low.
  • Fatty liver is seen in Kwashiorkor but not in marasmus.
  • Glucose tolerance is often normal, but hypoglycaemia may be seen in marasmus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kwashiorkor is a Protein energy malnutrition caused by inadequate intake of protein with good calorie intake. C/F: abdominal and peripheral edema due to decreased serum albumin levels. Body fat stores are depleted, but weight for height is normal.

 

Option C. Obesity is the condition in which excess fat is accumulated due to the increased energy intake and decreased energy expenditure.

 

 Option D. Irritable bowel syndrome is a G.I disorder of unknown cause. C/F: abdominal cramps or pain, bloating, flatulence, alternating periods of diarrhoea and constipation etc.

 

Educational objective:

 

Marasmus is a form of severe malnutrition characterized by energy deficiency; it typically presents with significant weight loss, wasting of muscle and subcutaneous fat, and growth retardation. The child's emaciated appearance, low body weight, and labored breathing are consistent with this diagnosis. The normal total protein level and slightly low albumin do not suggest kwashiorkor, which is typically associated with edema and more normal weight due to fluid retention.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 535.

questions.text: In the study of appetite regulation, which of the following polypeptides is known to increase appetite?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neuropeptide Y

 

Option A:

 

  • Polypeptides which increase appetite are Neuropeptide Y (NPY), Ghrelin, Melanin concentrating hormone (MCH), Orexin, Endo cannabinoid, Cholecystokinin (CCK), Polypeptide YY (PYY), Insulin and Cortisol.
  • Appetite decreasing factors are Leptin, Melanocyte stimulating hormone (MSH), Glucagon related peptide 1 (GLP1), Cocaine amphetamine related transcript (CART) and Serotonin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leptin: This hormone, produced by adipose (fat) cells, acts to reduce appetite and increase energy expenditure. It signals the brain that the body has enough energy stores, thus inhibiting hunger.

 

Option C. Glucagon-like peptide 1 (GLP-1): This hormone is released from the intestines after meals and works to decrease appetite and food intake, contributing to satiety.

 

Option D. Serotonin: This neurotransmitter has complex roles in appetite regulation, but it is generally associated with enhancing satiety and reducing food intake, particularly carbohydrate intake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The role of neuropeptide Y (NPY) in the regulation of appetite. NPY is a key neurotransmitter that stimulates hunger and food intake, contrasting with hormones and neurotransmitters like leptin, GLP-1, and serotonin, which generally work to reduce appetite and promote satiety.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 537.

questions.text: Considering the health risks associated with obesity, which of the following conditions is an obese individual at increased risk for?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D:

 

  • In obesity, decreased sensitivity of peripheral tissues to insulin and decreased number of insulin receptors in adipose tissue cells with elevated plasma insulin levels are seen.
  • Obesity is associated with increased cardiovascular risk.
  • Increased waist to hip ratio (abdominal obesity) is a risk factor.
  • The major effects of obesity are increased risk of coronary artery disease, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, metabolic syndrome, insulin resistance,  hyperglycemia, hyperlipidaemia (increased LDL and decreased HDL), obesity and a reduced lifespan.
  • Calorie-fat restricted diet may retard aging process and extend the lifespan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atherosclerosis: Obesity can contribute to the development of atherosclerosis through mechanisms such as inflammation and increased cholesterol levels.

 

Option B. Hypertension: Excess body weight is a significant risk factor for the development of high blood pressure, partially due to increased strain on the heart and arteries.

 

Option C. Diabetes mellitus: Obesity is a major risk factor for type 2 diabetes, as it can lead to increased insulin resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obesity is a well-documented risk factor for a variety of health conditions, including atherosclerosis, which is the buildup of fats, cholesterol, and other substances in and on the artery walls; hypertension (high blood pressure); and diabetes mellitus, particularly type 2 diabetes. These conditions are part of the metabolic syndrome, which is often associated with obesity.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 536.

questions.text: What is the caloric value per gram for fat?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 9kcal/g

 

Option A:

 

  • The energy content of food materials is measured in calories.
  • One calorie is the heat required to raise the temperature of 1g of water through 1oC.
  • The calorific value of nutrients is known as energy density.  

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 527.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient visits a clinic for a routine health check-up. During the visit, the patient's Body Mass Index (BMI) is calculated as part of a comprehensive health assessment. The patient's BMI falls within the range of 20-25. Based on this BMI range, how should the patient's weight status be categorized according to standard health guidelines?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Normal

 

Explanation:

 

BMI (Body Mass Index) is a standardized measure used to assess weight status relative to height. It is calculated using the formula: BMI = Weight (kg) / [Height (m)]
According to the World Health Organization (WHO) and most international health guidelines, BMI classifications are:
 

  • Underweight: BMI < 18.5
  • Normal weight: BMI 18.5-24.9
  • Overweight: BMI 25.0-29.9
  • Obesity class I: BMI 30.0-34.9
  • Obesity class II: BMI 35.0-39.9
  • Obesity class III: BMI 40.0
     

Since the patient's BMI falls within the range of 20-25, this is classified as normal weight according to standard guidelines.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Overweight: This category applies to individuals with a BMI between 25 and 29.9 kg/m, which is above the patient's calculated range.

 

Option C. Obesity class I: This refers to individuals with a BMI between 30 and 34.9 kg/m, which is significantly higher than the patient's BMI.

 

Option D. Obesity class II: This describes individuals with a BMI between 35 and 39.9 kg/m, which is even further from the patient's calculated BMI.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 536.

questions.text: In the context of nutrition and digestive health, dietary fibers play a crucial role in maintaining a healthy gut. Among the following, which components are classified as dietary fibers?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All the above

 

Option D:

 

Dietary fibers encompass a variety of plant-based substances resistant to digestion and absorption in the human small intestine. Cellulose, hemicellulose, and pectin are all components of dietary fibers. Cellulose and hemicellulose are found in the cell walls of plants and contribute to the structural integrity of the plant, while pectin, also found in plant cell walls, is known for its gel-forming properties and is often used as a gelling agent in food products. All these components contribute to dietary fiber's health benefits, including aiding digestion, promoting gut health, and preventing constipation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 531.

questions.text: A nutritionist is discussing the importance of amino acid profiles in plant-based diets with a group of medical students. The nutritionist emphasizes the concept of a "limiting amino acid" in various food sources. When considering pulses as a primary protein source, which amino acid is typically the limiting factor that could affect the overall protein quality of the diet?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Methionine

 

Option B:

 

Methionine is often the limiting amino acid in pulses, such as beans, lentils, and peas. Pulses are generally rich in lysine, which is more commonly the limiting amino acid in grains but tend to have lower levels of sulfur-containing amino acids like methionine and cysteine.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lysine: Incorrect because pulses are usually a good source of lysine. It is more often the limiting amino acid in grains rather than in pulses.

 

Option C. Tryptophan: While tryptophan can be a limiting amino acid in some protein sources, it is not typically the limiting amino acid in pulses.

 

Option D. Leucine: Leucine is an essential amino acid important for muscle protein synthesis but is not commonly the limiting amino acid in pulses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The limiting amino acid in pulses is Methionine.

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 534.

questions.text: In nutritional science, when evaluating the quality of dietary proteins, one particular source is often used as the reference standard due to its optimal amino acid profile and digestibility. Which of the following is considered the reference standard for comparing the nutritional quality of proteins?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Egg proteins

 

Option B:

 

Egg protein is considered the reference standard or gold standard in evaluating dietary protein quality. This is because:

  • It contains all essential amino acids in the ideal proportions needed by humans.
  • It has high biological value (BV), high digestibility, and a perfect chemical score.

 

Nutritive value of proteins.

 

 

Note:

  • BV: Biological Value
  • NPU: Net Protein Utilization
  • PER: Protein Efficiency Ratio

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Milk proteins: While high in quality, milk proteins are not the primary reference standard for protein quality comparison. However, they are still considered a good source of essential amino acids.

 

Option C. Meat proteins: Meat proteins are complete and high-quality but are not the primary reference standard for comparing protein quality. They vary in digestibility and amino acid profiles.

 

Option D. Fish proteins: Fish proteins are also complete and of high quality, but egg proteins are preferred as the reference standard due to their optimal balance of essential amino acids and digestibility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Egg proteins, particularly those from egg whites, are considered the reference standard for protein quality because they contain all the essential amino acids in the proportions required by the human body and are highly digestible. This makes egg protein an excellent benchmark for comparing the nutritional quality of other protein sources.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 534.

choices.text: Low protein and low GI
High protein and high GI
Low protein and high GI
High protein and low GI

questions.text: A patient who has recently achieved their weight loss goals is consulting with a dietitian to discuss a sustainable eating plan for weight maintenance. The dietitian emphasizes the importance of macronutrient composition and the glycemic index (GI) of foods in maintaining a healthy weight. Based on current nutritional guidelines and research, which type of diet is most commonly recommended for weight maintenance?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High protein and low GI

 

Option D:

 

  • Eating food items with a high glycaemic index is associated with obesity.
  • For longer-term weight management, a low GI diet is the best to follow.
  • Low GI diets will significantly reduce total and LDL cholesterol levels.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Low protein and low GI: While low GI foods are beneficial for maintaining stable blood sugar levels, a low protein intake might not sufficiently promote satiety and could lead to increased calorie consumption from other sources.

 

Option B. High protein and high GI: High GI foods can cause rapid spikes in blood sugar levels followed by sharp declines, which may increase hunger and lead to overeating, counteracting the benefits of a high protein intake.

 

Option C. Low protein and high GI: This combination is least effective for weight maintenance as it may lead to increased hunger and overeating due to the lower satiety provided by low protein and the blood sugar spikes caused by high GI foods.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For weight maintenance, a diet that includes high protein and low glycemic index (GI) foods is often recommended. High protein content can increase satiety and reduce overall calorie intake, while low GI foods lead to more stable blood glucose levels, reducing hunger and helping to prevent overeating.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 540.

questions.text: A clinical nutritionist is reviewing patient cases and notes different physiological and pathological states that might affect nitrogen balance in the body. Negative nitrogen balance is a condition where the excretion of nitrogen exceeds its intake, indicating a loss of body proteins. In which of the following scenarios is negative nitrogen balance most likely to be observed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic fever

 

Option B:

 

  • Nitrogen balance can be measured by calculating the dietary intake of protein nitrogen (16% of the weight of ingested proteins) and then comparing it with the daily nitrogen excretion.
  • A normal healthy adult is said to be in nitrogen balance if the dietary intake of                                                             nitrogen (I) = daily loss in urine (U) + feces (F) + skin (S).

l=U+F+S

  • In the above scenario, the person ingests 100 g (which amounts in 16 g of ingested nitrogen) of proteins/day and excretes 25 g of nitrogen/day.
  • Hence, the rate of nitrogen excretion is more than that of ingestion and the person is in a state of negative nitrogen balance which is common in illness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pregnancy: Incorrect because pregnancy is typically associated with a positive nitrogen balance due to the increased need for protein for fetal growth and maternal tissue expansion.

 

Option C. Convalescence: Incorrect because convalescence, the period of recovery after illness or medical treatment, is generally associated with a move towards a positive nitrogen balance as the body repairs and rebuilds tissues.

 

Option D. Growth period: Incorrect because growth periods, such as childhood or adolescence, are characterized by a positive nitrogen balance due to the increased need for protein for tissue growth and development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factors Affecting Nitrogen Balance

 

  • Growth: Positive nitrogen balance exists.
  • Hormones: Growth hormone, insulin and androgens promote positive nitrogen balance and corticosteroids causes negative nitrogen balance.
  • Pregnancy: Positive nitrogen balance due to the growth of fetus.
  • Convalescence: after an illness or surgery will be in positive nitrogen balance, due to active regeneration of tissues.
  • Acute illness: Negative nitrogen balance immediately after surgery, trauma and burns.
  • Chronic illness: Malignancy, uncontrolled diabetes mellitus and other debilitating diseases show negative nitrogen balance.
  • Protein deficiency/ Starvation: The deficiency of single essential amino acid can cause negative nitrogen balance.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 533.

questions.text: A dietitian is discussing the energy content of various nutrients with a group of students during a nutrition class. The focus is on understanding how different types of nutrients contribute to the total caloric intake. Based on their energy-yielding capabilities, which of the following has the highest calorific value?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Palmitic acid

 

Option B:

 

  • The energy content of food materials is measured in calories.
  • One calorie is the heat required to raise the temperature of 1g of water through 1oC.
  • The calorific value of nutrients is known as energy density.     
  • The calorific value of fat is 9 kcal/g.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Glucose: 4 kcal/g.

 

Option C. Albumin: 4.2 kcal/g.

 

Option D. Ethanol: 7 kcal/g.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 528.

questions.text: In evaluating a case of kwashiorkor in a pediatric patient, a clinician notes various clinical features associated with this form of malnutrition. Which of the following is NOT typically associated with kwashiorkor?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypercalcemia

 

Option B:

 

Kwashiorkor, a severe form of malnutrition caused by protein deficiency, is not typically associated with hypercalcemia (high blood calcium levels). Common features of kwashiorkor include hypoalbuminemia (low blood albumin levels), which contributes to edema; hypomagnesemia (low blood magnesium levels) may occur due to inadequate nutritional intake; and normoglycemia (normal blood sugar levels) can often be maintained despite malnutrition. Hypercalcemia is not a characteristic finding in kwashiorkor.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hypoalbuminemia: True, as low albumin levels due to inadequate protein intake are a hallmark of kwashiorkor, contributing to the characteristic edema.

 

Option C. Hypomagnesemia: True, this can occur in kwashiorkor due to overall poor nutritional intake, including deficiencies in magnesium.

 

Option D. Normoglycemia: True, blood sugar levels can remain within normal ranges in kwashiorkor if the caloric intake, albeit poor in protein, is sufficient.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

The hallmark features of Kwashiorkor are hypoalbuminemia, poor wound healing and edema.

 

  • Hypoalbuminemia: If the albumin values << 2 g/dL is a biochemical marker in cases of Kwashiorkor (Marasmus: not so low).
  • IgG increases due to associated infections.
  • Fatty liver is seen in Kwashiorkor due to decreased lipoprotein synthesis, but not in marasmus.
  • Glucose tolerance is often normal, but hypoglycaemia may be seen in marasmus.
  • Hypokalaemia and dehydration is seen when there is diarrhoea.
  • Hypomagnesaemia is present.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 535.

questions.text: Which of the following carbohydrates is recognized as indigestible by the human digestive system?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pectin

 

Option D:

 

  • Dietary fibres are contributed by the unavailable or indigestible carbohydrates in the diet.
  • They contribute to the bulk of the stool and assist in normal bowel movements.
  • Cellulose, hemicellulose, pectin, alginates and gums are the usual glycan’s functions as dietary fiber.
  • Pectins are mixtures of homoglycans made of galacturonic acid and arabinose present in fruits like apples and berries.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lactose: This is a disaccharide found in milk that is digestible by humans, although some individuals may lack the enzyme lactase, leading to lactose intolerance.

 

Option B. Glycogen: This is a storage form of glucose in animals, including humans, and is digestible by human enzymes.

 

Option C. Fructose: This is a monosaccharide found in many fruits and some vegetables and is readily digestible by humans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pectin, a type of dietary fiber, is indigestible by human digestive enzymes and contributes to dietary fiber intake, supporting digestive health. In contrast, other carbohydrates like lactose, glycogen, and fructose are digestible and provide energy to the body.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 82,531.

questions.text: Which vitamin, when consumed in excess, is most likely to be excreted in the urine rather than stored in the body:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin C

 

Option B:

 

Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is a water-soluble vitamin, meaning that the body does not store it in large amounts. Excess vitamin C is excreted in the urine, making toxicity from overconsumption less common compared to fat-soluble vitamins.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: This is a fat-soluble vitamin stored in the liver, not typically excreted in urine in significant amounts.

 

Option C. Vitamin D: Also fat-soluble, vitamin D is stored in body fat and the liver, not routinely excreted in urine.

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Another fat-soluble vitamin, vitamin K is stored in the liver and fatty tissues, with minimal excretion in urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Water soluble vitamins are excreted in urine.

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 463.

questions.text: Among the following pairings of nutrients and associated health conditions, identify the one that is incorrectly matched:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Iodine-dry skin

 

Option C:

 

Iodine deficiency is more commonly associated with thyroid dysfunctions, such as goiter and hypothyroidism, rather than primarily causing dry skin. While severe hypothyroidism can lead to dry skin, the direct association of iodine with dry skin is less specific compared to its role in thyroid health.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Folate - Anemia: Correctly matched. Folate deficiency can lead to megaloblastic anemia, characterized by the production of abnormally large red blood cells.

 

Option B. Zinc - Immunodeficiency: Correctly matched. Zinc is crucial for normal immune system function, and deficiency can lead to an increased susceptibility to infection.

 

Option D. Iron - Anemia: Correctly matched. Iron deficiency is a well-known cause of anemia, specifically iron-deficiency anemia, characterized by a decreased number of red blood cells or less hemoglobin in each cell.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 502-525.

questions.text: Among the following substances, which is known to absorb the least amount of water?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mucilage

 

Option A:

 

  • Mucilage is seen in plant species and is a polysaccharide helps to store food and water but not absorb as much water as dietary fibres.
  • Dietary fibre has several beneficial effects such as
    • It adds bulk to the diet.
    • It can absorb 10–15 times its own weight in water, draws fluid into the lumen of the intestine and increases the bowel motility and thereby promotes normal laxation.
    • Soluble fibre delays gastric emptying resulting in a sensation of fullness → delayed emptying → reduced peaks of blood glucose following a meal.
    • Consumption of soluble fibre lowers LDL levels by increasing faecal bile acid excretion and interfering with bile acid absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemicellulose: This plant-derived fiber can absorb water and is effective in adding bulk to the stool. It is generally considered more effective than lignin in water absorption.

 

Option C. Gums / Lignin: Lignin is the least hydrophilic among the options, known for its water-resistant properties. Gums, however, are quite hydrophilic and effective in water absorption, similar to mucilage and pectin.

 

Option D. Pectin: Found in fruits, pectin is highly hydrophilic and effective in absorbing water, forming a gel-like substance that can aid in easing constipation.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 531.

questions.text: Match the vitamin deficiency to the presenting symptoms:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-a, 2-c, 3-b, 4- d

 

Option A:

 

Thiamine deficiency, or vitamin B1, is known to cause beriberi, which can present as dry beriberi with neurological deficits. Riboflavin deficiency, or vitamin B2, often results in mucocutaneous symptoms such as glossitis and angular stomatitis. Pantothenic acid deficiency can lead to 'burning foot syndrome', characterized by neuropathy with a burning sensation in the feet. Finally, pyridoxine deficiency, or vitamin B6, can lead to several issues including seizures and anemia, particularly sideroblastic anemia, due to its role in hemoglobin synthesis and neurotransmitter metabolism.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan  9/e: p 486.

questions.text: Which of the following options correctly pairs the vitamins with their associated diseases?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-a, 2-b, 3-c, 4- d

 

Option A:

 

  • 1-a (Vitamin A - Phrynoderma): Phrynoderma, also known as toad skin, is associated with Vitamin A deficiency.
  • 2-b (Vitamin D - Rickets): Rickets, a disease characterized by bone softening and deformities, is caused by Vitamin D deficiency.
  • 3-c (Vitamin E - Anemia): Vitamin E deficiency can lead to hemolytic anemia due to oxidative damage to red blood cells.
  • 4-d (Vitamin K - Hemorrhagic disease of the newborn): Vitamin K deficiency can lead to bleeding problems, particularly hemorrhagic disease in newborns, due to its role in blood clotting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan  9/e: p 468-476.
